summary: Do you take requests for fics? If so, where can I submit one? Here, or somewhere else?
question: Do you take requests for fics? If so, where can I submit one? Here, or somewhere else?
answer: I do! You can head over to @superwholock-viking-marquise and leave one in the ask box. Some people also leave them as replies in the “Masterlist” post, or you can private message me. Really, anywhere works so long as it’s somewhere where I’ll see it. Thanks for asking!

summary: Have you read any of Neil Gaiman's other books?
question: Have you read any of Neil Gaiman's other books?
answer:
Again I must ask, is that you, Neil? Get out of my asks, sir! Lol.

But no, I have not. I honestly don’t know where to start. I read Good Omens almost 10 years ago, and it’s been a favorite ever since, but otherwise, I don’t know what a good place to take off from there would be. I’ve been thinking about American Gods, since a girl in one of my Viking history classes did a presentation on it.

Any suggestions?

summary: Hello #GoodOmens fans! Should you be in London next Tuesday, the 28th May, you might want to come to the Odeon Luxe Leicester...
body: Hello #GoodOmens fans! Should you be in London next Tuesday, the 28th May, you might want to come to the Odeon Luxe Leicester Square in the late afternoon or early evening. It will be our big Premiere so you’ll see lots of the cast. I would love to shake your hand and say hello and THANK YOU for all your support of our beloved show. I will be clean on the night. And not blonde. Pollution. 😉

summary:
“One of the nice things about Time,
Crowley always said, was that it was steadily taking him further away from the fourteenth...
caption:
“One of the nice things about Time, Crowley always said, was that it was steadily taking him further away from the fourteenth century, the most bloody boring hundred years on God’s, excuse his French, Earth.”

tags: this was supposed to be funny then it became so sweet omg i'm giving myself a cavity
summary: Okay but Crowley takes up painting in retirement. Like, imagine he just ends up binge watching Bob Ross on Netflix and then...
body:
Okay but Crowley takes up painting in retirement. Like, imagine he just ends up binge watching Bob Ross on Netflix and then suddenly bursts into Aziraphale’s study screaming, “ANGEL, I MUST PAINT!”

He doesn’t use any of his “magic” either, he practices because it’s what Bob Ross would have wanted!!

Yeah, so he fucks up! So what if he smears paint everywhere, on his face, his clothes, Azirphale’s clothes (”Sorry, love.”)? Who cares that he’s going through canvasses and sketch pads full of rough drawings? Yeah, he collects palettes. Of course he experiments with watercolors and oil paints!

Crowley listens to his soul music collection while he paints, too. Blares it the hell up until Aziraphale complains that he can’t concentrate on reading. It’s cool though because Adam tells him about noise-cancelling headphones and Aziraphale gets to listen to his classical music and read in peace while Sam and Dave play in Crowley’s studio.

Months go by, and every day Crowley wakes up, kisses his husband good morning, gets a GIANT cup of coffee and goes back to painting. He emerges only to have his meals with Aziraphale, and if he can twist his arm a bit, his angel takes him for a walk because “Some air would do you good, dear, and perhaps you’ll be inspired.”

Aziraphale buys him books to study and brings him hot cocoa or lemonade to his studio where he has to be careful not to trip on the old bed sheets that are lining the floor. Whenever he brings him refreshments, Crowley quickly throws a sheet over his work, refusing to let his angel see his work in progress.

“It’s not quite a painting yet, love,” he explains.

Aziraphale only laughs. “Well, do let me know when it’s ready.”

One afternoon, Crowley comes into the den, where Aziraphale is reading. He is in his speckled painting smock and his hair is disheveled.

“Angel?” 

“Yes, dearest?”

“It’s ready.”

“What is?”

“My painting. You can see it now if you’d like.”

Aziraphale instantly closes his book and gives him a grin. “Of course I want to see it!”

Crowley winces and smirks. “It’s not very good.”

“I’m sure it is, love,” his angel says. 

Crowley sighs. “Come on, then. Be gentle.”

“You’re so dramatic.” Aziraphale grasps his hand and follows him to the studio.

He pauses in the door and he softly gasps.

A huge canvas is resting on the easel and it’s an exquisite rendition of a garden.

No, wait a moment…it’s the Garden.

Aziraphale steps closer to it. “Oh…darling.”

It’s just as he remembered it: lush trees of all sorts, animals grazing and frolicking, and fruit-bearing bushes scattered here and there. There was a glorious stream running through the Garden and he could make out the silhouette of a large shoal of fish under the surface, and birds of all kinds in a bright blue sky.

“Crowley…this is…marvelous.”

“Angel…” 

“I know you’ll never believe me, but love, this is…beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. You’ve captured every detail! It’s amazing.”

Crowley finally grinned. “I don’t remember too much, but that particular day is one I won’t forget.”

“How so?”

Crowley stepped to his side and pointed to the left corner of the canvas. “See that wall there?”

Aziraphale looked and realized that it was the Eastern Gate, and upon it, overlooking the desert, were two figures with wings.

“Oh, yes…” the angel smiled sweetly and looked at him. “I’ll never forget that day either.”

“It was before the first rain,” Crowley said, linking his arm with Aziraphale, “and there upon the Eastern Gate, I met an angel with a misplaced flaming sword.”

Aziraphale giggled.

“And…I didn’t know it then, but…that flustered being in white seemed to pop up everywhere I went.”

“Dear, please…”

Crowley kissed his cheek. “From that day in the Garden, to when he put a ring on my finger, to where he is now.”

The angel’s eyes stung with tears and he kissed him.

He turned back to the painting and admired the figures at the Eastern Gate for another moment.

“I love you, my angel.”

“I love you, too, darling. And I’m so proud of you.”

Crowley looked down at his smeared smock with a bashful smile. “Thank you…” he muttered.
body_abstract:
Okay but Crowley takes up painting in retirement. Like, imagine he just ends up binge watching Bob Ross on Netflix and then suddenly bursts into Aziraphale’s study screaming, “ANGEL, I MUST PAINT!”

He doesn’t use any of his “magic” either, he practices because it’s what Bob Ross would have wanted!!

The angel’s eyes stung with tears and he kissed him.

He turned back to the painting and admired the figures at the Eastern Gate for another moment.

“I love you, my angel.”

“I love you, too, darling. And I’m so proud of you.”

Crowley looked down at his smeared smock with a bashful smile. “Thank you…” he muttered.

Crowley stepped to his side and pointed to the left corner of the canvas. “See that wall there?”

Aziraphale looked and realized that it was the Eastern Gate, and upon it, overlooking the desert, were two figures with wings.

“Oh, yes…” the angel smiled sweetly and looked at him. “I’ll never forget that day either.”

“It was before the first rain,” Crowley said, linking his arm with Aziraphale, “and there upon the Eastern Gate, I met an angel with a misplaced flaming sword.”

Aziraphale giggled.

“And…I didn’t know it then, but…that flustered being in white seemed to pop up everywhere I went.”

“Dear, please…”

Crowley kissed his cheek. “From that day in the Garden, to when he put a ring on my finger, to where he is now.”

The angel’s eyes stung with tears and he kissed him.

He turned back to the painting and admired the figures at the Eastern Gate for another moment.

“I love you, my angel.”

“I love you, too, darling. And I’m so proud of you.”

Crowley looked down at his smeared smock with a bashful smile. “Thank you…” he muttered.
trail.content_abstract:
Okay but Crowley takes up painting in retirement. Like, imagine he just ends up binge watching Bob Ross on Netflix and then suddenly bursts into Aziraphale’s study screaming, “ANGEL, I MUST PAINT!”

He doesn’t use any of his “magic” either, he practices because it’s what Bob Ross would have wanted!!

tags: i'm usually fairly good about remembering to tag spoilers but i am human |D
summary: this just arrived on my doorstep and it’s a beautiful book. nice and heavy with wonderful formatting and beautiful illustrations...
body:
this just arrived on my doorstep and it’s a beautiful book. nice and heavy with wonderful formatting and beautiful illustrations and photos. i’ve only just skimmed it (mostly just looked at the pictures) but already the amount of love put into this show is apparent just from that. there’s just so much love for the book, for the creative process, for all the hard work and passion that went into this, and of course, all the love for terry….i was in tears by the time i reached the end and i haven’t even read it properly yet |D

i don’t plan on posting much from this until the 31st (and i assume there are others who are already working on getting wonderful HD scans of it out there and who can do it much better than i can. but i do plan to read it and perhaps engage in some of the content from it in the next week. i will try very hard to remember to post things under the “good omens spoilers’ tag. ^^

summary: I was thinking about Good Omens all day - as one does - and my brain went into full “in this essay I will–“ mode, except this...
body:
I was thinking about Good Omens all day - as one does - and my brain went into full “in this essay I will–“ mode, except this time I actually will write that essay so. Here it goes.

The essay started forming in my head when I wondered why among all my fandoms that get new content this year, Good Omens is the thing I anticipate the most. By far. So of course I started analyzing what made it so special to me and what made this story stand out so much compared to other stories I’ve been following and getting excited about lately.

First thing I realised was, Good Omens is a story which contains maybe 10% of plot in an ocean of plot-driven stories. Every subplot can be reduced to a one-sentence-long summary. An angel and a demon try to prevent the Apocalypse, rather badly. A descendant of a witch tries to prevent it too, but loses a book of prophecies. The Antichrist spends 11 years of his life not knowing he’s the Antichrist and in the end refuses to start the Apocalypse. And so on. Instead of focusing on spectacular plot twists the so-called shock value, Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett decided to pack the book with brilliant language, humor, well-built characters and what’s most important, complex relationships between them. Therefore, knowing literally every single plot point in Good Omens still won’t spoil the enjoyment of reading it, because the plot - while being very clever - is not the most important thing in the book. Which is not to say Good Omens is boring or predictable - on the contrary. But surprises never scream to you from the book’s pages, “I’m a plot twist! Look! Be surprised!“, rather slip in naturally, in a convincing way, and are carried out incredibly smartly. Reading Good Omens, you never know what will come next, but you won’t feel cheated by things happening out of the blue. There is quite a briliant method to this madnes.

The next aspect of the book that emerged from my chaotic thoughts was the characters, specifically, to no suprise of anyone reading this, Aziraphale and Crowley. Characters who stay with you long after you’ve finished the book. Characters who, compared to the crowd of cool, flawlessly-looking characters I see everywhere are pretty much their exact opposite. And all I have to say in this matter boils down to one thing - Aziraphale and Crowley, unlike thousands of other fictional characters I’ve seen in my life, are allowed to be genuinely, deeply human. Not the usual, although still greatly appreciated by me, “they messed up really badly and now have to fix it” or “they have to fight their weaknesses” kind of human. It goes deeper than that. Aziraphale and Crowley are allowed not to be cool, they’re allowed to be awkward, embarrassing and natural to the extent that is very rarely seen on the screen or paper. Reading about them you’re not left with the feeling that you could relate to them if only [insert reasons why you can’t relate to them here]. No, in most cases you see yourself in both of them, in their strenghts and weaknesses and beliefs and attitude. They could be someone you meet every day, someone within the very reach of your hand.

Tying my previous points together, I’d like to move on to another aspect of the book - the plot is just the canvas used as a foundation for character arcs and developing relationships between the characters. What would be the point of the Armageddon almost happening if Aziraphale and Crowley didn’t tell each other, “Nice knowing you?“ What would be the point if Adam didn’t choose his friends over his powers? What would be left of this scene if we stripped it from Neil and Terry’s thoughts about the very core of what makes us human? In Good Omens, the most important question answered as the story goes is never “what?“. It’s who?, it’s why? and it’s what lies underneath it?. No things happen just for the sake of things happening. Too often do I see creators forgetting that they’re allowed not to push the plot forward all the time. Even if you only stop to make a witty joke or leave a footnote.

And the very last aspect I wanted to discuss is the book’s message. Few fictional works I’ve read/watched have left me feeling so comforted. Good Omens is a book which is hard to close and feel indifferently towards it, because if there’s one thing it keeps telling you, it is, “Isn’t it wonderful to be human? Isn’t it wonderful to be a part of this world and enjoy it? Isn’t it the point of living your life to love, to try to do the right thing, to fail, to love books and old cars, to form unlikely friendships, and have free will, and cling to this world because it’s a bloody fantastic world?“ This is what really stays with the reader. Great plot will leave you delighted, surprised, and amazed by the creator’s brilliant imagination. A meaningful message will affect your everyday life and the way you look at yourself and how you treat other people. A true work of art crosses the border between fiction and reality to dare us to think, to wonder, to feel, and to hope.

These are the stories that never truly leave us, and Good Omens is one to me.

To finish this post - I know it was pretty chaotic, and I know I only skimmed the surface of what could have been said here, but I had quite a few things boiling in my mind that I wanted to finally put into words. Still, if you actually got here, to the end of this post, thank you so much for reading. I really appreciate that.

Still, if you actually got here, to the end of this post, thank you so much for reading. I really appreciate that.

title: You Forget We Were In Love
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2VIJvJL

by CaptainSlow

In the very Beginning of it all, there were an angel and… an angel.

Words: 8442, Chapters: 3/10, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Good Omens - Neil Gaiman & Terry Pratchett
  • Rating: Explicit
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: Aziraphale (Good Omens), Crowley (Good Omens)
  • Relationships: Aziraphale/Crowley (Good Omens)
